newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds inch higher, spreads tighten.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds inch higher, spreads tighten.

text.p: Most U.S. mortgage-backed securities traded modestly higher on Wednesday, getting their lift from buyers of Ginnie Mae paper, mortgage experts said.
Yield spreads to Treasuries were unchanged to slightly tighter and trading volume was relatively thin, they said.

"Mortgage bankers were selling a little bit and there was (some) buying of Ginnie 8.0s," said one trader at a large U.S. investment firm. He said the buying of Ginnie paper amounted to about $150 million.
Other market participants said mortgage activity was at a virtual standstill.
"It's been very quiet today. The only thing that's been going on is (the) buying of Ginnie 8.0s," another trader added.
In pass-throughs, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5-percent coupons were up 2/32 at 99-02/32, yielding 95 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae was up 2/32 at 99-03/32, and Freddie Mac issues were up 1/32 at 99-07/32.
The five-year note was off 2/32 at 6.65 percent, while the 10-year note was down 1/32 to yield 6.80 percent.
The U.S. Treasury auctioned about $16.5 billion of two-year notes at a high yield of 6.328 percent.
